There was a lot more to dictators than just Germany.

Italy went fascist in 1922, and Portugal in 1926. Neither were really caused by economic downturns. In both cases, traditional conservatives (with the support of corporate interests) in unstable governments essentially cut deals with nationalists/fascists to help stabilize things and stop the spread of Socialism and/or Communism- and then were in turn unwittingly consumed by the dictators they unleashed. Japan had a long and rather interesting road to their own version of totalitarianism, going as far back as the Meiji Reformation in the late 1800s. It's not simply that poor economic conditions caused the rise of Japan's version of fascism- they had much deeper issues. The video even touches on how Spain went fascist because of their notoriously fractured society in the mid-1930s, but leaves out that their problems go way further back- Spain has had "issues" with making their government function going as far back as the early 1700s.

Countries like Austria, Romania, Croatia, and Hungary went fascist after the Depression. While economic conditions played a role (especially in Austria's case- but their economic problems went back to the collapse of their empire near the end of World War I), again, it was more that traditional conservatives in weak governments essentially tried to cut deals with fascists and wound up being dominated by them (OK, Croatia basically got conquered by Nazi Germany and a pro-Nazi government was installed...). Additionally, there was the perception by that point that fascism truly worked- after all, by the mid-1930s Italy had been fascist for over a decade and seemed to be doing pretty well (it wasn't, but Mussolini was pretty good at hiding it). Austria for example, was afraid of being absorbed by then-newly Nazi-ruled Germany, and in 1933 Engelbert Dolfuss decided to copy Mussolini, who was seen at the time as the powerhouse dictator of Europe, to gain his favor and get him to guarantee their independence- and it worked for a while, until Hitler got cozy with Mussolini in 1938. When Dollfuss was assassinated by Nazis in 1934 (his successor Schuschnigg continued the "Austrofascist" government), Mussolini actually tried to convince England and France to join an alliance with him to fight Germany in the event that Germany tried to annex Austria. It was called the Stresa Front and it was (briefly) a thing!

Even Nazi Germany had that effect; look at how Hitler actually came to power. Traditional conservatives like Papen and the DNVP- with the support of business interests- tried to cut a deal with him because they feared socialists and communists more than they feared Hitler's brand of insane, populist nationalism. And as soon as Hitler got into office, he masterfully manipulated events (and cut a deal with another moderately conservative party, the Centre) to have Germany turned into a dictatorship- the Nazi takeover took less than two months from Hitler's appointment to chancellor to the passage of the Enabling Act.

Including Stalin here is a bit curious too. Stalin didn't ride into power on a wave of discontent regarding economic conditions, he more or less manipulated the already-established Soviet bureaucracy to his advantage, defeated/exiled his political opponents, and stepped into the power vacuum that Lenin's death caused. There were many factors in Lenin's seizure of power, which yes included- but was far from limited to- economic conditions. Soviet Russia, like Imperial Japan, was its own special type of animal.

So while the basic premise that economic conditions can contribute to the rise of dictators has some validity, I would argue that weak governments and wealthy corporate interests allowing nationalist demagogues into positions of power is a far bigger concern.

I just want to say that calling that swastika a "Buddhist symbol" is an incredibly incomplete historical statement. Use of the swastika has been recorded as far back as 10,000 BCE, and it has been found in Bronze and Iron age art throughout Asia AND Europe in pretty much every single culture, as well as some places in Africa. Yes, it was misappropriated and had its image destroyed, yes it was a Buddhist symbol, but the implication made with that statement is that the Nazi party based their use of it on an appropriation of the symbol FROM Buddhist art, but this is clearly not the case. They used it as a reference to historical Germanic art, where it was also prevalent. Along with Celtic art, Sami art, Greco-Roman art, Illyrian, Armenian, Slavic, Polish, Hindu, Jainist, Ashanti, and interestingly enough various native American cultures from Panama to Canada, including Navajo art, based on which it had been used on Arizona roadsigns.
In the time immediately preceding the rise of the Nazi party, it had been used in symbolism for the Theosophical society, a Danish brewery, an Icelandic shipping company, an Irish laundry company, both the Finnish and Latvian Air Forces, parts of the Polish military, a Swedish industrial company, the Oslo municipal power station, the 45th Infantry Division of the US Army...there is even a town in Ontario founded in 1908 which is named "Swastika".

The place where the Nazi party likely appropriated it from was the Order of the New Templars, which was the first to use it in the context of "racial consciousness" and "Aryan aesthetics". But that group also used the Fleur-de-Lys in their symbolism, so the Nazis could have easily taken and destroyed that symbol, as well.

Basically, the only point I am trying to make here is that I think it is incomplete to the point of inaccuracy to simply say that the swastika was a Buddhist symbol that had been misappropriated.

Short note from a German: In Germany the word Kristallnacht or Reichskristallnacht actually has propaganda implications now. The more neutral term is considered Progromnacht or Reichsprogromnacht.

Some constructive criticism for the CrashCourse writing team: Our history teachers taught us that "Kristallnacht" (literally translates to crystal night) is a cynical euphemism invented by the Nazis to glorify the destruction they caused that night. It's better to call it "Pogromnacht", since the word "Pogrom" describes an organised massacre of helpless people, which accurately described what happened.

Another point to make is that the ideals of communism and nazism were very different and Stalin was not as bad as Hitler (I know, low bar but true) and Stalin was not the extent or even a true representation of communism/socialism given there was no meaningful redistribution of wealth and power, indeed a curtailing of workers' assemblies and such (union off socialist soviet republics as it was). One should debate the merits of revolutionary change over reformative change, especially given the current climate of legislative impasse in the US for example. What happened in Germany that led to the rise of Hitler was baked into the Versailles treaty, the perceived blame of WW1 on the German people entirely and the inherent instability and unpopularity of the Weimar republic among other reasons.
It should also be noted that when facing radicalism from both the left and right, power always chooses the right to further in face of the left. Perhaps it is because at the heart of communism is the belief in the equality of man, in all its forms and a criticism of the structures of power in capitalism. These structural arguments can often mask the human side of these relationships and blind the 'revolutionaries' to the awful means that can be invoked to achieve laudable ends (democracy, equality on the one hand, gulags and lawlessness on the other). It should also be noted that despite the mistakes of the early Stalinist russia it basically won WW2 and became one of the two great superpowers of the world. So there's that. And the US and Europe are guilty of many evils, the former in the oppression of the latin america, later in the Middle East and the latter in the long history of colonialism, including of the former. Nazism and the system of fascism has no redeeming qualities and no high ideals beyond the brazen adulation of the masculine dictator and the oppression of convenient scapegoats as well as overt militarism and war-mongering (something Lenin and then Stalin were keen to avoid in the interwar years, even to their loss). The fact that socialist idealists and workers of the world were inspired by the ideals of soviet communism at the time whilst rich businessmen and royalty were sympathetic to fascism suggests the moving of class interests from the democratic arena to the dictatorial one. Interest groups for either side were simply fed-up with relying on democratic systems of representative government to provide for/keep the people in line (depending if you were poor/rich, proletariat/bourgeoisie). It's a warning to democratic systems everywhere that you are there but by the consent of the governed and special interests willing to play by the rules. If you fail to deliver a sustainable social contract, that society is likely to erode, sometimes in an alarmingly rapid fashion. I believe in democracy and free speech first and foremost for this reason, and in that sense the ultimate anti-fascist/socialist whatever label you want to give me. I believe that more democracy is always better, that speech should always be defended, no matter how taboo but I cannot deny that sometimes voting and talking is not enough. Sometimes you need armed revolution or where the law protects and the media shows to the public you can instead resort to non-violent peaceful protest (civil rights movement, antiwar movement).
I will never pick up a gun, but would I condemn anyone who fought Nazism or in the Spanish Civil War against Franco? No. Sometimes armed struggle is necessary, like in the American war of independence, or the French revolution. Or even the American Civil War. Sometimes violence is the only option left. And I hope I never see that day in my lifetime.
